The electrochemical conversion of NO into value-added NH3 presents a promising strategy for addressing energy challenges and mitigating environmental pollution. Although noble metal-based catalysts currently predominate in electrocatalytic NO reduction reaction (eNORR) research, their practical deployment remains constrained by excessive costs and limited atomic utilization efficiency. Non-noble metal corrolazines have shown remarkable catalytic capabilities in homogeneous systems, presenting innovative possibilities for eNORR implementation. Herein, we engineered a two-dimensional Fe-corrolazine single-atom catalyst (2D-Fecor SAC) through alkynyl-bridged assembly of Fe-corrolazine units. Then extensive density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to explore its structural and electronic properties, as well as its eNORR catalytic behavior. The results show 2D-Fecor SAC exhibits excellent stability, and each Fe atom retains its catalytic active center, which can effectively adsorb and activate NO. Notably, 2D-Fecor SAC exhibits superior eNORR performance via an N-distal pathway, achieving a low limiting potential of −0.44 V with significant suppression of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Crucially, aqueous environments enhance the catalytic efficiency and further reduce the limiting potential to −0.18 V. This significant activity originates from synergistic effects: the corrolazine framework enables precise electron transfer modulation while Fe centers facilitate efficient charge transport. Our work establishes a novel approach for developing cost-effective electrocatalysts to simultaneously remediate NO pollution and produce sustainable ammonia. Graphical abstract Novel 2D-Fe-corrolazine SAC can effectively activate NO and promote its conversion to NH3 through strong (NO)σ→(Fe)d donation and (Fe)d→(NO)π* back-donation interactions via N-distal mechanism. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Corrolazine Single-atom catalyst (SAC) 2D-nanomaterials NO reduction Heterogenization Electrocatalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitric oxide is a gas that poses significant risks to human health and contributes substantially to environmental pollution. It stems mainly from manufacturing activities, automobile emissions, and combustion processes involving fossil fuels [1–3]. The continuous rise in atmospheric NO concentrations will inevitably contribute to a spectrum of severe environmental issues, including ozone layer depletion, haze formation, and acid rain [4–6]. Earlier research efforts have concentrated predominantly on the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitric oxide to H2O and N2, utilizing NH3 or H2 as reductants [7,8]. However, SCR technology still faces challenges such as high costs and environmental pollution. Therefore, it is imperative to explore novel, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly technologies for NO removal. Ammonia serves as a critical raw material in both industrial and agricultural sectors and is currently predominantly synthesized by means of the Haber-Bosch method [9,10], which is characterized by its high energy consumption and significant environmental impact [11–15]. Although electrocatalytic reduction of nitrogen to ammonia (NRR) is regarded as a sustainable approach [16,17], the inherent stability and low solubility of the N2 molecule hinder its practical application. Given that NO has lower bond energy and better solubility compared to N2, electrochemically reducing NO to NH3 significantly reduces the overpotential [18], thereby enhancing the efficiency of NO removal. Currently, the research on the electrocatalytic reduction of NO to NH3 is rapidly increasing [19–21], mainly focusing on noble metal catalysts exemplified by Pt [22,23], Pd [24], Au [25], and Ir [26]. Nevertheless, the limited availability and prohibitive expenses associated with such noble metal-based materials constrain their large-scale application. Therefore, non-precious metal electrocatalysts for NORR have recently risen to prominence as a vanguard scientific domain. For instance, Wang et al. [27] studied various metals embedded in graphene and identified Co-N4 as a stable and active NORR electrocatalyst. Li's group [28] employed Ru nanoplates to achieve the electrocatalytic reduction of low-concentration NO to NH3, demonstrating high selectivity and Faraday efficiency (65.96 %). Liu et al. [29] explored the catalytic properties of 13 transition metal two-dimensional (2D) phthalocyanine sheets (Pc), identifying 2D Co-Pc sheets as the optimal NORR catalyst with appropriate NO adsorption energy and a relatively low limiting potential (−0.58 eV). Among non-precious metals, Fe is the second most abundant transition metal on Earth after Al. Due to its low cost and excellent catalytic activity, Fe has been extensively utilized in catalytic research [30–32]. Wang and his collaborators [33] studied the catalytic performance of single-atom catalysts featuring various transition metals anchored on pyridinic-defect graphene for NO-to-NH3 reduction, revealing that Fe-N4 exhibits high NH3 selectivity and superior catalytic activity. Despite these advancements, designing and developing highly selective and active NORR catalysts for efficient NH3 synthesis remain a great challenge. Following its emergence in 2011, heterogeneous single-atom catalysis (SAC) [34], has become a focal point in catalysis research owing to its well-defined atomic architecture of active centers, the highest atomic utilization efficiency, and superior catalytic performance [35–41]. Notably, SACs offer an exceptional platform for developing heterogeneous electrocatalysts for the electrochemical NO reduction reaction (eNORR), while largely preserving the characteristics of molecular catalysis. Specifically, the supported single atoms at catalytic active sites exhibit structural and electronic properties analogous to those observed in homogeneous catalysts. Moreover, two-dimensional material-supported single-atom catalysts exhibit significant promise in key electrocatalytic processes including the carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [42–44], NRR [45–47], and NORR [48–50]. Therefore, the design of novel 2D SACs with high stability and distinctive electronic properties holds substantial research significance and considerably practical application value. The corrolazine [51–53], a heteromacrocyclic aromatic compound characterized by a tetrapyrrolic architecture with π-conjugated subunits connected by three nitrogen atoms at the meso-positions and two directly linked pyrrole rings, has garnered increasing attention owing to its superior photoelectric and catalytic properties. Unlike porphyrins, corrolazines possess a smaller cavity due to the absence of one meso-carbon atom. This structural characteristic enables corrolazines to stabilize high-valence metals [54–58] more effectively, thereby enhancing their catalytic performance. Furthermore, recent studies [59–61] have demonstrated that metallocorrolazines can serve as potential electrocatalysts. Additionally, the catalytic efficiency of metallocorrolazines can be modulated through structural modifications at the meso and β- positions, as well as by applying an oriented external electric field. For example, Mn-corrolazine and Fe-corrolazine exhibit efficient catalytic activity in converting methane into methanol with the regulation of an external electric field [62–65]. Moreover, our research group [66] has designed a novel 2D SAC based on a Mn-corrolazine unit, which demonstrates remarkable catalytic activity in the oxidation of alkanes to alcohols. To further explore the application of metallocorrolazine in eNORR, we first investigated the structural and electronic characteristics of Fe-corrolazine monomer, along with its dimer and tetramer (di‐Fecor, tetra‐Fecor) formed via linear ethynyl bridging. Then we assembled a planar 2D Fe-corrolazine SAC (2D-Fecor SAC) through expanding the fundamental units of the Fe-corrolazine dimer along both axial directions [67,68]. The calculation results show that the Fe-corrolazine monomer, dimer, and tetramer exhibit excellent stability and possess the capability to adsorb and activate NO. Moreover, the 2D SAC constructed from Fe-corrolazine units demonstrates high structural stability, with each monomer retaining its intrinsic molecular characteristics. Furthermore, the 2D-Fecor SAC exhibits superior electrocatalytic activity for NORR to NH3 and higher selectivity compared to HER. The excellent eNORR performance originates from the moderate adsorption affinity of NO and Fe servicing as a charge transfer channel to facilitate the eNORR. 2 Computational methods The structural and electronic characteristics of Fe-corrolazine and its polymeric systems were computationally investigated using Gaussian 16 [62]. DFT computations employing the B3LYP hybrid functional with effective core potential (ECP) methodology adopted the LANL2DZ pseudopotential basis set for iron atoms, while all other atoms were treated with the 6-31G (d, p) all-electron basis set. Vibrational frequency analysis was implemented to validate stationary points and derive thermodynamic parameters. Kohn-Sham DFT computations were carried on the structural and electronic characteristics of 2D-Fecor SAC, as well as its adsorption capability for NO, employing the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [69]. All calculations employed the PBE-GGA functional to model electronic exchange-correlation potential. The PAW method, coupled with a plane-wave basis set featuring a cut-off energy of 500 eV [70], was employed to model the electron-ion interactions. DFT+U calculations were conducted using parameters U = 4.0 eV and J = 1.0 eV [71,72], following the method proposed by Dudarev et al. [73]. The conjugate gradient method was employed to optimize the geometry without any restrictions, and the convergence error of the forces on all atoms was 0.02 eV/Å. Grimme's method in dispersion correction (DFT-D3) was utilized to calculate the van der Waals interaction [74,75]. Periodic boundary conditions were applied along the growth axes of the 2D-Fecor SAC with a vacuum layer exceeding to 15Å to avoid interlay interaction between the adjacent units of the periodic 2D materials. Fe-corrolazine and polymers geometries were optimized using a 1 × 1 × 1 k-point grid, and the partial density of states (PDOS) was calculated using a 5 × 5 × 1 k-point grid. A 5 × 5 × 1 k-point grid played a role in 2D-Fecor SAC structure optimization, and an 11 × 11 × 1 k-point grid was adopted for PDOS calculations. The degree of NO adsorption and activation was assessed using the Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) [76]. The stability of 2D-Fecor SAC was evaluated via AIMD simulations for 40 picoseconds at 298 K utilizing a time interval of 1 fs. Atomic Bader charges were calculated to evaluate the properties of bonding and electron for NO adsorbed on single-atom catalysts [77]. The binding energies (BEs) of di-Fecor and tetra-Fecor were defined by the following Eqs. (1) and (2) [66] to evaluate the stability of Fe-corrolazine polymers. (1) B E di − F e cor = 2 E HC ≡ CH + 2 E Fe − cor − E di − F e cor − 4 E H 2 (2) B E tetra − F e cor = 8 E HC ≡ CH + 4 E Fe − cor − E tetra − F e cor − 16 E H 2 where E [ x ] refers to the energies of the ethyne, Fe‐corrolazine, di‐Fecor, tetra‐Fecor, and H2. The adsorption energy (E ads) was defined by (3) (3) E a d s = E total − E substrate − E adsorbate where E total , E substrate and E adsorbate represent the energies of the NO adsorbed on Fe-corrolazine or polymers or 2D-Fecor, Fe-corrolazine or polymers or 2D-Fecor substrate, and free NO molecule, respectively. According to the Computational Hydrogen Electrode (CHE) model [78], the free energy variation (∆G) for all eNORR stages were computed by (4) [79,80]. (4) Δ G = Δ E DFT − Δ E ZPE − T Δ S + n e U + Δ G pH where Δ E DFT was directly obtained by the DFT calculated results. The variation of zero-point energy (∆E ZPE) and entropy (∆S) at 298.15K are both determined through the vibrational frequency analysis using VASPKIT code [81]. Here, e U denotes the applied potential and n indicates the quantity of electrons transferred. Δ G pH signifies the pH-induced free energy variation and is calculated by ( 5 ) [82]. (5) Δ G pH = 2.303 k B T pH The limiting potential (U L) was utilized for assessing catalytic performance, which is described as ( 6 ) : (6) U L = − Δ G max e where Δ G max refers to the highest Gibbs energy variation during the whole reaction pathway. An implicit solvent model [83] was used to assess the influence of aqueous solvent and model the impact of externally applied electrode potential. In addition, the profiles of ∆G across the pH range of 0-14 were calculated to investigate electrolyte and pH effects on reaction mechanisms [84]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and stability of 2D-Fecor SAC Firstly, we investigated on the structure and electronic properties of the Fe-corrolazine monomer and its polymers (di‐Fecor, tetra‐Fecor). The results indicated that the ground state of the Fe-corrolazine monomer is quartet state, with almost all of the unpaired electrons residing at the Fe atom. Moreover, during the polymerization process, its structure and electronic properties demonstrated excellent stability. The detailed research findings are provided in the Supporting Information (SI). These results motived us to further develop and design a 2D single-atom catalyst, namely 2D-Fecor SAC, based on Fe-corrolazine unit by extending di-Fecor along the x and y axes with β-β ethynyl linking. As demonstrated in Fig. 1 (a) and Table S2, the optimized 2D-Fecor is planar structure with the Fe-N bond lengths being in the range of 1.236−1.237 Å, which are comparable to those observed in di-Fecor, indicating that the 2D-Fecor maintains the structural characteristics of the di-Fecor. It is worth noting that Liberto and Pacchioni et al. [85–87] systematically investigated the stability of SACs under electrochemical conditions, including pH, applied voltage, metal-support interaction, and other factors. They proposed an efficient approach to predict their stability, emphasizing that the binding energy binding energy of the free metal atom to the support is a key factor. Therefore, we calculated the binding energy of Fe on 2D-Fecor to evaluate its stability. As shown in Table S3, the binding energy of Fe on 2D-Fecor is -7.87 eV and the dissolution potential (U diss) is 0.86 V, which reveals that 2D-Fecor can remain stable in electrochemical conditions, thereby preventing dissolution in working conditions. Moreover, AIMD simulations show the 2D-Fecor retains its stability without significant deformation or reconfiguration, as shown in Fig. 1(b), and the calculated phonon spectrum (Fig. S10) demonstrates only a negligible imaginary frequency, suggesting that the system is dynamically stable [88–90]. Furthermore, the electron spin density of 2D-Fecor is predominantly localized on two Fe atoms with the magnetic moments being 2.46 and −2.50 μ B, respectively. Meanwhile, the analysis of the charge state nature of Fe in 2D-Fecor shows that the charge of Fe atom in 2D-Fecor was 1.272 |e|. (Table S4) Therefore, the single-atom catalytic activity centers of Fe atoms in 2D-Fecor are retained, similar to that in the Fe-corrolazine monomer. Moreover, the 2D-Fecor contains numerous 12-membered C12, 14-membered C12N2 and 16-membered C16 pores, with dimensions of approximately 5.68 × 4.11 Å2, 6.69 × 5.82 Å2, and 5.38 × 5.23 Å2, respectively. The size-variable pores permit appropriately sized molecules to traverse the 2D-Fecor SAC framework, potentially facilitating molecular reactions on its surface. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 1(c), 2D-Fecor exhibits conductor. Therefore, 2D-Fecor is promising as a superior platform for electrocatalysis. 3.2 Adsorption and activation of NO Effective NO adsorption and activation on the catalyst constitute the crucial initial phase of the NORR process, determining the success of subsequent hydrogenation steps. Three potential adsorption modes, namely N-end-on, O-end-on and NO-side-on, were examined to identify the optimal adsorption configuration and its associated binding strength. Notably, the NO-side-on mode spontaneously converts to the N-end-on configuration following full structural relaxation during optimization. As demonstrated in Fig. 2 (a and b), the N-end-on adsorption is the most stable with E ads of −1.10 eV. Upon adsorption on Fe-corrolazine, the N-O bond length increases from 1.168 Å in the free NO molecule to 1.178 Å and the Bader charge analysis indicates that 0.16 |e| charge is transferred from Fe-corrolazine to NO via Fe-N bond. Moreover, as revealed by the PDOS in Fig. S7, pronounced overlap between Fe-3d and NO-2p orbitals near the Fermi level indicates strong electronic coupling between these states. As shown in Fig. 2h, the lone pair electrons from the N of NO undergo partial delocalization into the empty d orbital of Fe, while the electrons from Fe-3d orbitals simultaneously transfer to the empty π* orbital of NO, indicating effectively bonding between Fe and N of NO. Therefore, NO can be effectively adsorbed and activated on Fe-corrolazine, which is further substantiated by the integral crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) of Fe-N of −3.77. We further investigated the adsorption of NO on di-Fecor and tetra-Fecor. The N-end-on configuration is energetically most favorable with E ads of −1.07 eV, as demonstrated in Fig. 2(d and e). The N-O bond elongates from 1.168 Å in the free NO molecule to 1.178 Å upon adsorption on di-Fecor, which is consistent with that observed for the Fe-corrolazine monomer. Moreover, as shown in Fig. S6 and Fig. S7, the PDOS indicates the significant overlap between the Fe-3d orbitals and NO-2p orbitals below the Fermi level, demonstrating that NO can be adsorbed on di-Fecor originating from donation/backdonation interaction between Fe and NO, with 0.12 |e| charge being transferred from di-Fecor to NO via Fe-N bond, which can be further substantiated by the ICOHP of Fe-N of −2.27. Similarly, tetra-Fecor also exhibits the properties analogous to those of the Fe-corrolazine monomer in terms of NO adsorption and activation. As shown in Fig. 2g, upon adsorption on tetra-Fecor, NO receives 0.25 |e| charge from tetra-Fecor, with the N-O bond length stretching to 1.187 Å. These results indicate that during the polymerization of Fe-corrolazine, the Fe atom maintains a single-atom catalytic active center, which is beneficial for constructing 2D-Fecor SAC for catalyzing the NO-to-NH3 conversion. As demonstrated in Fig. 3 a, the adsorption energy of NO on 2D-Fecor is −0.62 eV for the O-end-on configuration and −1.32 eV for N-end-on configuration, while the NO-side-on configuration exhibits structural instability and spontaneously reconfigures into the N-end-on configuration. Therefore, the N-end-on configuration is optimal for NO adsorption, with the N-O bond slightly elongating from 1.168 Å in the free NO molecule to 1.186 Å upon adsorption. As shown in Fig. 3b and 3c, the PDOS reveals significant hybridization between the 2p orbitals of the N-end-on adsorbed NO and the Fe-3d orbitals of 2D-Fecor below the Fermi level, originating from the (NO)σ→(Fe)d donation and (Fe)d→(NO)π* back-donation interactions, resulting into NO receiving 0.21 |e| from 2D-Fecor, demonstrating effective adsorption and activation of NO on 2D-Fecor. This is further substantiated by ICOHP of N-O, which is decreasing from −19.33 in its free state to −19.02 in the adsorbed state. 3.3 Electrocatalysis mechanism of NORR The possible pathways of NO reduction to NH3 include dissociation mechanism and association mechanism [91]. As discussed above, NO prefers molecular adsorption in N-end-on 2D-Fecor rather than dissociative adsorption due to the strong NO bond with a bond order of 2.5. Therefore, here we only study the association mechanism of NO electrocatalysis reduction reaction on 2D-Fecor. As shown in Fig. 4 , four possible mechanisms of eNORR, including N-distal, O-distal, N-alternating and O-alternating mechanisms are explored. The N-alternating and O-alternating pathways involve sequential proton-electron pairs transfers to N and O atoms of adsorbed NO, yielding H2O and NH3. In the O-distal pathway, consecutive proton-electron pairs donations first target the O atom to form H2O, followed by N atom conversion to NH3. Conversely, the N-distal pathway initiates with dual H+/e- transfers to the N atom, generating two H2NO intermediates, subsequent O atom conversion to H2O, and final NH2 transformation into NH3. As illustrated in Fig. 5 , the O-distal mechanism initiates with an energetically demanding step (0.95 eV) where the first proton-electron pair hydrogenates *NO to form *NOH. Subsequent hydrogenation involves two consecutive proton-electron pairs transfers to the O atom of *NOH, yielding H2O while leaving the N atom adsorbed on 2D-Fecor. The second step is characterized by a release of 0.68 eV. The remaining N atom then undergoes three sequential proton-electron pairs additions to generate *NH3, accompanied by progressive energy releases of 0.51 eV, 1.59 eV, and 1.50 eV. This establishes the initial *NOH formation step as the potential-determining step (PDS) with a limiting potential of −0.95 V. In contrast, the O-alternating pathway differs in its second hydrogenation step, where the proton-electron pair targets the N atom to produce *HNOH, though following hydrogenation stages mirror those of the O-distal pathway. Notably, both mechanisms share identical PDS characteristics (−0.95 V limiting potential). However, thermodynamic analysis reveals a 0.62 eV lower Gibbs energy for the *N intermediate compared to *HNOH, strongly favoring the O-distal mechanism over its alternating mechanism. In the N-distal pathway, the initial hydrogenation preferentially targets the N atom of the adsorbed *NO rather than the O atom, requiring only 0.44 eV to form *HNO through the first proton-electron pair transfer, which is a significantly lower energy barrier compared to energy barrier of 0.95 eV for O atom activation in the O-distal mechanism. Sequential hydrogenation proceeds with two protonation steps on the N atom, generating *H2NO and the second step exhibits energy release of 0.27 eV. Notably, the third proton-electron pair shifts to the O atom, converting *H2NO to *H2NOH with an energy liberation of 0.94 eV. Subsequent H2O removal occurs via a fourth protonation (1.06 eV release), leaving adsorbed *H2N on the 2D-Fecor surface. The pathway culminates in a fifth hydrogenation step (1.50 eV release) that completes NH3 formation. This mechanism identifies the *HNO generation step as the PDS, characterized by a limiting potential of −0.44 V. The *NH3 desorption from 2D-Fecor exhibits a modest activation barrier of 0.27 eV, accompanied by favorable entropy gain that thermodynamically drives the liberation process. Contrastingly, the N-alternating pathway diverges at the second hydrogenation stage, where oxygen activation by an H+/e- pair generates *HNOH (−0.45 V limiting potential). While subsequent hydrogenation steps mirror those in the N-distal mechanism, this oxygen-targeting second step emerges as the potential-determining step (PDS), exhibiting a 0.01 V higher energy demand than its N-distal counterpart. Thus, the N-distal mechanism represents the most favorable pathway among all considered mechanisms. For exploring the effect of electrolyte and pH for the N-distal reaction mechanism of eNORR, the profiles of ∆G for the eNORR N-distal mechanism on 2D-Fecor under various pH (pH = 0, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 14) and the variation of U L of *NO→*HNO were investigated. As demonstrated in Fig. 6 and Table S10, declining H+ concentrations trigger a systematic upward shift in Gibbs free energies of intermediates, accompanied by a progressive increase the limiting potential of PDS. This thermodynamic evolution confirms that the strongly acidic regime (HCl, pH=0) achieves optimal eNORR performance on 2D-Fecor, of which the lowest limiting potential of PDS −0.44 V. The detailed discussion is provided in the Supporting Information (SI). To elucidate solvent effects on 2D-Fecor catalyzed eNORR, we systematically compared the free energy (ΔG) profiles of the optimal N-distal pathway under aqueous-phase conditions and gas-phase conditions. Notably, the N-distal pathway exhibits a significant reduction in limiting potential from −0.44 V in gas phase to −0.18 V in solvated environment as shown in Fig. 5 and S8, indicating aqueous solvation significantly enhances the electrocatalytic performance of 2D-Fecor SACs for eNORR. Furthermore, for investigating the influence of the constant potential on eNORR catalyzed by 2D-Fecor. We evaluated its electrocatalytic behavior under applied potentials matching the limiting potentials of both pathways: −0.44 V (N-distal) and −0.95 V (O-distal). As revealed in Fig. 5, maintaining these critical potentials renders all eNORR steps energetically favorable across the catalyst surface. This potential-dependent energetic landscape confirms that maintaining threshold potentials effectively suppresses energy barriers, thereby promoting continuous catalytic turnover on the 2D-Fecor active sites. Moreover, we calculated reaction energy profiles at the equilibrium potential of −0.75 V (−3.73 eV/5), as depicted in Fig. S9. At the equilibrium potential, the overpotential of the NO reduction reaction was significantly reduced., indicating that the reaction proceeds with greater smoothness and efficiency under these conditions. 3.4 The product selectivity on the 2D-Fecor SAC As is well known, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) constitutes the primary competitive reaction in eNORR, primarily due to the comparable limiting potentials of HER and eNORR. Therefore, here we further calculated the limiting potential of the HER on 2D-Fecor. As illustrated in Fig. 7 , the U L for the HER is −0.94 V. Although this value is comparable to that of the eNORR in O-distal mechanism, it substantially exceeds the characteristic 0.43 V threshold observed in the N-distal pathway for eNORR, indicating that the 2D-Fecor exhibits excellent selectivity for eNORR to NH3. Therefore, 2D-Fecor SAC can serve as an effective candidate to realize high selectivity for eNORR towards ammonia. 3.5 Internal mechanism of NORR catalytic activity on the 2D-Fecor SAC To unravel the charge transfer dynamics governing catalytic activity of 2D-Fecor SAC in eNORR, we systematically investigated electronic evolution in the N-distal pathway. As demonstrated in Fig. 8a, Bader charge analysis reveals that the Bader charges of Fe exhibit minimal variation throughout the entire eNORR process, which is approximately 1.27 |e| and the oxidation state of Fe is located between +2 and +3 [92], whereas the corrolazine ring and adsorbed NO exhibit complementary charge fluctuations. This charge compensation pattern identifies the macrocyclic ligand as an electron buffer, with Fe atoms functioning as charge relay centers during catalytic cycles. Additionally, the interaction between NO and 2D-Fecor with ICOHP of −4.01 is stronger than that between HNO and 2D-Fecor with ICOHP of −3.94, as shown in Fig. 8 c and d and Table S13, revealing that the step of *NO → *HNO demands greater energetic input. However, upon the formation of HNO intermediate, subsequent proton-electron attacking processes become considerably easy with a reduction in energy requirements, which can be attributed to the substantial activation of the N-O bond. 4 Conclusions For effectively converting NO into value-added NH3, we designed a novel two-dimensional single atom catalyst 2D-Fecor via connecting Fe-corrolazine units with alkynyl groups. DFT calculations were conducted on its structural and electronic properties. The results show 2D-Fecor exhibits excellent stability and Fe atoms maintain their electronic configuration in Fe-corrolazine monomer, thereby enabling effective heterogenization of Fe-corrolazine. Moreover, NO can be effectively adsorbed and activated on 2D-Fecor, which is beneficial for further eNORR. Through comprehensive screening of four distinct eNORR pathways (O-distal, O-alternating, N-distal, N-alternating), computational analysis reveals the N-distal mechanism as the energetically optimal route for NH3 synthesis on 2D-Fecor, achieving a limiting potential of −0.44 V. Moreover, the competing HER is simultaneously suppressed, of which the limiting potential is up to −0.94 V. Notably, aqueous-phase operation further enhances catalytic efficiency, reducing the limiting potential to −0.18 V improvement over gas-phase conditions. The superior performance originates from synergistic charge buffering: the corrolazine macrocycle dynamically modulates electron reservoirs while Fe active centers facilitate directional charge transfer. These findings establish a mechanistic framework guiding experimental optimization of metal-macrocycle catalysts for sustainable NO-to-NH3 conversion. coredata.dc:description: The electrochemical conversion of NO into value-added NH3 presents a promising strategy for addressing energy challenges and mitigating environmental pollution. Although noble metal-based catalysts currently predominate in electrocatalytic NO reduction reaction (eNORR) research, their practical deployment remains constrained by excessive costs and limited atomic utilization efficiency. Non-noble metal corrolazines have shown remarkable catalytic capabilities in homogeneous systems, presenting innovative possibilities for eNORR implementation. Herein, we engineered a two-dimensional Fe-corrolazine single-atom catalyst (2D-Fecor SAC) through alkynyl-bridged assembly of Fe-corrolazine units. Then extensive density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to explore its structural and electronic properties, as well as its eNORR catalytic behavior. The results show 2D-Fecor SAC exhibits excellent stability, and each Fe atom retains its catalytic active center, which can effectively adsorb and activate NO. Notably, 2D-Fecor SAC exhibits superior eNORR performance via an N-distal pathway, achieving a low limiting potential of −0.44 V with significant suppression of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Crucially, aqueous environments enhance the catalytic efficiency and further reduce the limiting potential to −0.18 V. This significant activity originates from synergistic effects: the corrolazine framework enables precise electron transfer modulation while Fe centers facilitate efficient charge transport. Our work establishes a novel approach for developing cost-effective electrocatalysts to simultaneously remediate NO pollution and produce sustainable ammonia.
